Comment: **From the article:**  US manufacturing in the years following the covid pandemic has been booming—or at least the groundwork for such a boom is getting built. Until the most recent few months, spending on the construction of factories[ had been soaring](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PRMFGCONS). New facilities to build batteries, solar cells, semiconductors, electric motors, and other new technologies are springing up all around the country—or were[ until very recently](https://www.technologyreview.com/2025/04/21/1115511/canceled-climate-tech-projects/).  But there are already indications that the prospect of widespread tariffs could be [harming this boom. ](https://cepr.net/publications/trump-derails-manufacturing-boom/)For one thing, the specifics—how large, how long, and on what countries—seem to be constantly shifting. And that’s a big part of the problem: For manufacturers and investors, uncertainty is the killer of plans for expansion, new factories, and even the R&D that feeds into new products.  It’s that uncertainty, above all else, that could derail a reindustrialization still in the early stages for much of the country. If the Trump administration’s tariffs slow or even reverse such progress, the impact on the country’s economic and technological future could be devastating.
